title: Zanab247
author: Zanab247
content: My way to class this morning with some of my lovely course mate, someone raise this question that if our government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal how will i feel? I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. If your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel?  Will you be among the people that will be angry because i know there are some people in our various places that think BTC is a scam digital currency which is not true, will you go to make them to understand it better in a positive way?

comments.author: Z-tight
comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMI will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate.A bad idea to tell everyone around you that you have BTC's, after the party you may have just invited people to attack you physically and steal your BTC's, torturing you until you send it to them.Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMIf your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel? BTC is legal where i am. If the government make it a legal tender, then it makes spending it easier for me, so i will feel great.

comments.author: tiCeR
comments.body: Quote from: NeuroticFish on March 04, 2023, 06:01:24 PMQuote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMMy way to class this morning with some of my lovely course mate, someone raise this question that if our government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal how will i feel? I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. If your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel?  Will you be among the people that will be angry because i know there are some people in our various places that think BTC is a scam digital currency which is not true, will you go to make them to understand it better in a positive way?I'm not sure what country are you from, but Bitcoin is legal (ie not illegal) in most countries.However, if Bitcoin will become legal tender, ie I'll be able to pay for everything I want with Bitcoin if I want to, then I'll be indeed very happy.I wonder if making Bitcoin legal tender also automatically entails a tax exemption on realized gains? That is probably different from country to country? I would like to understand the legal implications of something becoming legal tender. Otherwise, making Bitcoin legal tender when you still have to pay taxes on realized gains at the time you make a purchase or pay your tax, there is still too much hassle involved in actually using it to buy stuff. The label "legal tender" isn't so interesting to me. A tax exemption would make Bitcoin way more useful, even if it is up to a certain limited amount for single item purchases.

comments.author: KaliLinux
comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMMy way to class this morning with some of my lovely course mate, someone raise this question that if our government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal how will i feel? I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. If your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel?  Will you be among the people that will be angry because i know there are some people in our various places that think BTC is a scam digital currency which is not true, will you go to make them to understand it better in a positive way?First of, for those that did not previously believe in BTCitcoin, it will no longer be a question of convincing them that Bitcoin is not a scam because they would have seen that even their Government has made it a legal tender and it is part of their official payment system.Secondly, I believe that even when this is so, some people might still be reluctant to spend their Bitcoin because I personally believe that most people see Bitcoin as an investment than a financial tool, especially during the bull season however, I think I would love that I will be able to spend my Bitcoin if I fell like it.

comments.author: Captain Corporate
comments.body: I guess it could be a good improvement over long term, not going to really change anything on the very quick short term, we already had such a devastating earthquake recently that changed the whole economical scene, we were doing terrible before, and now we have over 40+ possibly as high as 80 billion dollars worth of damages and that's least of the worries in the short term, we have 50+ thousand of our people died in it, so when you put that two together, bitcoin wouldn't matter anytime soon. However, in the long run, like in 10 years or so then we can start to see how amazing of a decision it was for sure.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: tiCeR on March 04, 2023, 06:18:15 PMI wonder if making Bitcoin legal tender also automatically entails a tax exemption on realized gains? That is probably different from country to country? I would like to understand the legal implications of something becoming legal tender. Otherwise, making Bitcoin legal tender when you still have to pay taxes on realized gains at the time you make a purchase or pay your tax, there is still too much hassle involved in actually using it to buy stuff. The label "legal tender" isn't so interesting to me. A tax exemption would make Bitcoin way more useful, even if it is up to a certain limited amount for single item purchases. Legal tender should not mean tax exemption, knowing that the state is, by definition, hungry for money.But if bitcoin becomes legal tender there might become pretty difficult to know who and how much bitcoin did spend, since the grocery store doesn't ask for your ID.I guess that sooner or later bitcoin will be recognized for what it is: another form of money. Then it should be no need for such tax and legal tender would be easy and normal. But governments need to be interested to do such a move, so my hopes are very low on that.

comments.author: drwhobox
comments.body: I don't think it is the right question to ask here  . Obviously, everyone in this forum will have a positive opinion about legalizing bitcoin in their respective countries. If you ask me what I do if my country legalizes bitcoin I would talk openly about bitcoin and I will encourage people to adopt bitcoin.But I think this dream of yours will not come true any soon, the government won't allow this to happen.

comments.author: Zanab247
comments.body: Neuroticfish, the country I came from BTC is illegal which is a big worry to us bitcoiners in the land but there are some promise some of the presidential candidates made during our general election that just concluded few days ago, that they will make Blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies available for the youths to make progress like El Salvador country.

comments.author: alik111
comments.body: Those who love Digital Currency don't think Bitcoin is a Scam or anything else. But Government think so. It should be legalized through the world to make new era of Currency system. I believe one day it will happen and in my country it will be legalized.

Happy, because people will be financially independent.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 06:44:50 PMNeuroticfish, the country I came from BTC is illegal which is a big worry to us bitcoiners in the land but there are some promise some of the presidential candidates made during our general election that just concluded few days ago, that they will make Blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies available for the youths to make progress like El Salvador country. Making Bitcoin/crypto illegal is stupid at best. The government makes (some of) the voters unhappy and also loses money it could get from taxing crypto gains.So getting it legal is an easy step and a win-win situation. The "like El Salvador" is another step, a much bigger and harder one. But I wish you good luck and may the right candidate win and also fulfill his promise!

comments.author: Bananington
comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PM I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. You can celebrate, but a party sounds very unnecessary to me, why will you want to host all the people into bitcoin in your environment, do you have any idea how many they will be and what it will cost you?  A big party like you have described will involve a lot of expenses for music, food, drinks and decoration, all these are unnecessary expenses, money that can be used for better things like even  buying more bitcoins to keep. Do not let your excitement make you make regrettable decisions.

comments.author: Fivestar4everMVP
comments.body: If the Government of my country legalize bitcoin, this indeed would be a great news and another big win for the entire bitcoin community, this simply means that i can now buy and sell my bitcoins through banks and no longer worry about having to trust other people to send me my money or bitcoin after transacting with them through P2P, this indeed looks like a good win and calls for celebration.But I wont celebrate anything, because even with the current ban on bitcoin transactions in my country, we are still buying and selling bitcoin and selling bitcoin without problems, and the beautiful thing is that, we are not paying any tax on our bitcoin earning/profit.But then, when bitcoin becomes legalized, it is very possible that the government and banks will start taxing our bitcoin transactions and profit, which to me, is not something i should be really happy about, but generally, and for the sake of bitcoin adoption, i will be happy for the legalization.

comments.author: lionheart78
comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMMy way to class this morning with some of my lovely course mate, someone raise this question that if our government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal how will i feel? I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. Being happy about the news is enough and I think spending too much money to host a party just because Bitcoin is legalized is a waste.  Aside from that, your security would be compromised because many people will know that you hold Bitcoin and might make your family and your life in danger because there is a possibility that you will be targeted by people who do bad thing to make money.Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMIf your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel?  Will you be among the people that will be angry because i know there are some people in our various places that think BTC is a scam digital currency which is not true, will you go to make them to understand it better in a positive way?In my country, BTC is already a mode of payment.  So we are free to spend BTC whenever we want.  I don't think it will make a huge impact if it becomes a legal tender but sure I will be happy if it happens.

comments.author: Hispo
comments.body: In my case, the country where I am from has already set some basic legality on Bitcoin, which means it is perfectly legal to buy, sell and hold Bitcoin in this territory. It has been this way even since before I started to get into Bitcoin and learn about it. on the other hand, Bitcoin is not legal tender here (I do not expect it to be anytime soon), if some mirage happened and we got Bitcoin as legal tender I would be certainly happy, because it would much to our local economy and people to understand handling one's asset by ourselves is nothing to be afraid of (if we do it responsibly).For those newbies who do not have much of an idea on the reach of Bitcoin legality, Ill leave this map over here. Which is easy to find in the wiki.Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legality_of_cryptocurrency_by_country_or_territory

comments.author: bittraffic
comments.body: It may have a big difference if my government considers BTC as legal tender, its already legal to use BTC here but the adoption is too slow I can only see 2 stores accepting BTC in my city. If it's the only reason that merchants will tend to accept BTC, then surely I would be happy to use my BTC to buy something from them. Keeping your privacy is better than partying and announcing to the public that you are an investor makes you look rich target for criminals.

comments.body: Quote from: Zanab247 on March 04, 2023, 05:51:17 PMMy way to class this morning with some of my lovely course mate, someone raise this question that if our government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal how will i feel? I told him that the day our government will announce that BTC is now fully legalized in the country, I will throw a big party to host all the bitcoiners in my environment to join me to celebrate. If your government decide to adopt BTC or make BTC legal in your country, how will you feel?  Will you be among the people that will be angry because i know there are some people in our various places that think BTC is a scam digital currency which is not true, will you go to make them to understand it better in a positive way? Pretty sure you guys have some pretty heavy restrictions against bitcoin in there, or your country has outrightly banned you. That's besides the point though. The fact that a country could even control bitcoin in manners like these irks me sometimes, coz it makes me ask if bitcoin's decentralized nature is really that powerful enough to warrant being used in some places, and then I remember if it weren't this decentralized governments left and right will have vied for power already since bitcoin's takeoff in 2018. Quote from: bittraffic on March 04, 2023, 08:54:47 PMIt may have a big difference if my government considers BTC as legal tender, its already legal to use BTC here but the adoption is too slow I can only see 2 stores accepting BTC in my city. If it's the only reason that merchants will tend to accept BTC, then surely I would be happy to use my BTC to buy something from them. Keeping your privacy is better than partying and announcing to the public that you are an investor makes you look rich target for criminals. It will take time for it to happen. The government can legislate all bylaws helping people consider bitcoin as a form of legal tender but without proper education and support from the public, no one will ever use bitcoin for payments at all.

comments.author: The Cryptovator
comments.body: It will be my most desired surprise, to be completely truthful. Because my government now gives Bitcoin absolutely no recognition. Also, the government is overly restrictive when it comes to Bitcoin use. Someone must be punished if they are found out. If the government decides to legalize it in that circumstance. I'll be too thrilled. I own Bitcoin and will also accept it for payment in my business. All we have to do is make it legal, and we'll celebrate differently.

comments.author: Cantsay
comments.body: I think I'll be glad because now those who have been scared that Bitcoin might start to change their view of Bitcoin and the adoption of Bitcoin will surely increase and most service will eventually start implementing Bitcoin as a payment method in their businesses and that would be a wonderful feeling. And it's definitely going to affect Bitcoin market in a positive way because the demand of Bitcoin Will surely increase and those who have been hodling reasonable amount of BTC for quite sometime might end up making good profits from their stash.
